. Hamilton is closely tied to its sister town, Wenham, sharing a school system, library, recreation department and commuter rail station. In 2010, the community of Hamilton-Wenham was listed among the "Best Places to Live"

The Town of Hamilton has long been known for its association with equestrian and agricultural activities. Hamilton is continually exploring new ways to grow, while embracing its rich and storied history.   

With 14.9 square miles of winding roads, rolling hills, green forests, and miles of open fields, Hamilton is beautifully rural, peaceful, and inviting.

From Boston, take I-93 North to Route 128 towards Gloucester/Rockport.  Ext. 20A off of Route 128 onto Route 1A.  Follow Route 1A through North
, into Hamilton.  Trip is about 32 miles, 30-35 minutes.

content=This historical Methodist Camp is home for many S. Hamilton residents.  It includes numerous smaller neighborhoods with small houses full of character. Each house is painted in bright colors with unique architectural designs.

content=Home of General George S. Patton's historic WWII military tank, this park has walking, running, and biking paths, a playground, public baseball fields, tennis courts, basketball and volleyball courts,and the community swimming pool. During the summer, there are local musical acts featured in the park's center gazebo.
content=A ground-based observatory for scientific observation of the sun.
content=Boating and swimming, many hidden spots for romantic picnics and getaways.
content=Country club with golf course, tennis courts, swimming pools, and a few acres of open field where polo is played every Sunday in the spring.
content=Local theater company creates fun, lively versions of classic Broadway plays and musicals, casting of both children and adults.

content=Indigenous art from the far North. Sculptures and prints produced by Inuit artists, carvings by Yupik artists in Alaska and Siberia, embroidered reindeer leather jewelry from Sami artists in Lapland, and carvings and prints by artists from the Pacific Northwest. Handmade antique sleigh tables, snowshoe chairs, and other fine décor inspired by the far North.
content="French boudoir inspired" boutique, features clothing lines from numerous upscale designers, providing pretty, but pricey outfits.

content=Small, certified organic supplier of seasonal vegetables, fruits, flowers, local cheeses, and other products Breeds heritage livestock, hosts parties and functions for individuals and communal events.
content=Small, family run pizzeria with salads, subs and more.
content=The original pizzeria of Hamilton, salads and subs of all sorts.
content=Small, quiet and cozy café for breakfast, lunch or a late-afternoon snack.

content=Small coffee shop with baked goods, coffee drinks, wraps, small sandwiches, ice-cream and frozen yogurt. Adorably decorated in light pastel colors, with a handful of small sitting areas and tables.
content=Restaurant and bar.  It can be difficult to get a table at this small, intimate tavern, a local favorite.

content=Popular restaurant and bar. American fare and pub food, upscale environment invites a crowd of older residents and young professionals. Extensive beer selection includes national and locally brewed lagers and ales. Fisherman's Brew ([Gloucester], MA), Wachusett Blueberry Ale, and many more New England brews. Wines from around the world. Specialty drinks including original creations such as the Kiss in the Dark Martini.
content=Local, international and generic beers, extensive wine list includes all types and flavors.
, a city located directly on the Atlantic Ocean, has numerous beaches, sprawling state parks, shopping and night life.
is the next-door neighbor to Hamilton with shopping, restaurants, museums, parks and smaller beaches.

is the historic site of the Salem Witch Trials with numerous museums based upon its rich colonial history (Salem Witch Museum).  Salem is located directly on the ocean with many seaside restaurants and shops.
is another neighbor to Hamilton with Crane Beach and Estate, which are both beautiful and family-friendly areas.  Ipswich also has many great restaurants and small pubs in its quaint downtown area.

is the next town over from Gloucester with many seafood restaurants and a lively downtown shopping area called Bearskin Neck, where tourists and locals come to experience the small village of shops located only feet above the ocean.
